contact_form_links.description:
Ask HMRC’s digital assistant to get a quick answer to your query if you’re an employer.

If the digital assistant cannot help you, you can ask to transfer to an HMRC adviser if they’re available.
contact_form_links.title: Ask HMRC online

details.description: Contact HMRC with employer enquiries on PAYE, National Insurance contributions, Statutory Payments, stakeholder pensions and student loan repayments
details.more_info_contact_form:
If HMRC needs to contact you about anything confidential they’ll reply by phone or post.

Industrial action

Due to industrial action between 23 December 2024 and 14 February 2025, you may wait longer than usual to speak to an adviser using webchat.

If you can, you should use our online services rather than waiting to speak to us.

For example, you can:

  • check when you can expect a reply from HMRC to find out the status of your Construction Industry Scheme refund — you should only call us if the date has passed
  • use your business tax account to check your balance

For technical support with online services use the Online Services helpdesk.
details.more_info_webchat:
Advisers can only talk to you about PAYE for employers. They will not be able to transfer you to another webchat team.

You’ll need your employer reference number or accounts office reference number.

Contact the Income Tax: general enquiries helpline for enquiries about your personal tax affairs.

phone_numbers.description:
Phone HMRC to get help if you’re an employer. We’ll only be able to give general advice if you do not have your Accounts Office reference or PAYE reference number.

Before you call

This helpline may ask you some security questions. Make sure your details and address are up to date in your personal tax account and business tax account or you could fail telephone security. If you do not have a personal tax account, you can create one before you check your details.

Industrial action

Due to industrial action between 23 December 2024 and 14 February 2025, you may wait longer than usual to speak to an adviser.

If you can, you should use our online services rather than waiting to speak to us on the phone.

For example, you:

  • may get a quick answer to your query if you ask HMRC online
  • can check when you can expect a reply from HMRC to find out the status of your Construction Industry Scheme refund — you should only call us if the date has passed
  • use your business tax account to check your balance

For technical support with online services use the Online Services helpdesk.
phone_numbers.open_hours:
Our phone line opening hours are:

Monday to Friday: 8am to 6pm

Closed weekends and bank holidays.

You can also find out information in your business tax account.
phone_numbers.title: Employer Helpline

post_addresses.description:
Write to HMRC to get advice for employers.

You do not need to include a street name, city name or PO box when writing to this address.

Couriers should use a different address.
post_addresses.title: PT Operations North East England

details.description: Call HMRC to check the tax code of one of your employees

phone_numbers.description:
Call HMRC to check the tax code of one of your employees.

You’ll need your employee’s:

  • name
  • date of birth
  • address
  • National Insurance number

Before you call

This helpline may ask you some security questions. Make sure your business details and address are up to date in your business tax account or you could fail telephone security. If you do not have a business tax account, you can create one before you check your details.
phone_numbers.open_hours:
Our phone line opening hours are:

Monday to Friday: 8am to 6pm

Closed on Saturdays, Sundays and bank holidays.

You can also find out information in your business tax account.
phone_numbers.title: Employers Tax Code Helpline

details.description: Call or write to HMRC for advice if you’re a new employer or contractor

phone_numbers.description:
Before you call

This helpline may ask you some security questions. Make sure your business details and address are up to date in your business tax account or you could fail telephone security. If you do not have a business tax account, you can create one before you check your details.

Call HMRC if you’re an employer and need advice about:

  • stakeholder pensions
  • student loan repayments
  • the Construction Industry Scheme

  • PAYE in real time, including:

    • Statutory Sick Pay
    • Maternity and Paternity Pay

You will need your employer reference number, if you have one.

Industrial action

Due to industrial action between 23 December 2024 and 14 February 2025, you may wait longer than usual to speak to an adviser.

If you can, you should use our online services rather than waiting to speak to us on the phone.

For example, you can use your business tax account to check your balance.

For technical support with online services use the Online Services helpdesk.
phone_numbers.open_hours:
Our phone line opening hours are:

Monday to Friday: 8am to 6pm

Closed on Saturdays, Sundays and bank holidays.

You can also find out information in your business tax account.
phone_numbers.title: New Employer Helpline

post_addresses.description:
Write to HMRC for advice if you’re a new employer or contractor.

You do not need to include a street name, city name or PO box when writing to this address.

Couriers should use a different address.
post_addresses.title: National Insurance Contributions and Employers Office

details.title: Employers: support for new employers

contact_form_links.description:
Find out what to do if you’ve lost your:

  • user ID
  • password
  • activation code

You can also check service availability and see if there are any problems with our online services (including error messages).
contact_form_links.title: Get help with problems signing in

contact_form_links.description:
Ask HMRC’s digital assistant to find information about technical support with HMRC online services.

If the digital assistant cannot help you, you can ask to be transferred to a webchat with an HMRC adviser, if they’re available.
contact_form_links.title: Ask HMRC online

details.description: Contact HMRC with technical problems when using HMRC systems, sending forms online, error messages and using HMRC free software and tools

phone_numbers.description:
Call HMRC if you’re having technical problems with HMRC online services.

You can also call if you need extra support because your health condition, disability or personal circumstances make it difficult for you to use HMRC online services.

Do not use this helpline for:

  • tax queries — contact the helpline that deals with your tax, Child Benefit or tax credits affairs
  • issues with VAT online services — contact the VAT online services helpline

You can use Relay UK if you cannot hear or speak on the phone, dial 18001 then 0300 200 3600. Find out more on the Relay UK website.

Before you call

This helpline may ask you some security questions. Make sure your personal details and address are up to date in your personal tax account or business tax account or you could fail telephone security. If you do not have an account, you can create one before you check your details.
phone_numbers.open_hours:
Our phone line opening hours are:

Monday to Friday: 8am to 6pm

Closed weekends and bank holidays.

You can also find out information in:

  • the official HMRC app
  • your personal tax account or business tax account
phone_numbers.title: Get help using online services

details.description: Contact HMRC to get help sending payments to HMRC for PAYE Class 1 and Class 1A National Insurance, PAYE late penalties and PAYE Settlement Agreements

phone_numbers.description:
Call HMRC for general advice on how to pay employers’ PAYE.

You’ll need your Accounts Office reference when you call.

HMRC does not take payments on this line.

Check how to fix problems with running payroll before calling about errors on payroll payments (including re-allocations).
phone_numbers.open_hours:
Monday to Friday: 8am to 6pm
Closed weekends and bank holidays.

You can also find out information in your business tax account.
phone_numbers.title: Payment enquiry

post_addresses.description:
Find out how to pay by post for:

  • employers’ PAYE
  • PAYE late payment penalties
  • PAYE Settlement Agreements

You do not need to include a street name, city name or PO box when writing to this address.

Couriers should use a different address.
post_addresses.title: HMRC
